commentBody: TTOPs, ALOE, and ELIE Wiesel... it's summer on the grid!
Committed the sin of forgetting Edison’s middle name. Shame.
You guys forgot Minnesota.
I must confess: I filled in “neW z” for 10D and was prepared to give the constructor a proper eye roll for half the solve. Eventually, I realized that I’m the problem and the puzzle is great!

TIL that I didn’t know how to spell PLAGIARISMS.  A minor glitch in an otherwise smooth solve.  I only saw that the circled letters were state codes for pairs of states adjacent to the MISSISSIPPI —MI double S I double S I double P  I.

Other than the theme, this was a straightforward Monday-level solve. As for that theme ... bleh.  

Not only do you need to have at least a vague sense of US geography, you also need to know the USPS's official abbreviations for several states. Definitely not for the international audience that the NYT pretends they welcome
Percolated… SEEPED and not STEEPED?

Struggled with the sw corner. Not plagiarisms but manner and gain. However I appreciated Menlo park and Edison being so close together. Laughing at myself as I spent 5 months in Australia and know that at a sporting event it’s Aussie, Aussie, Aussie and Kiwi kiwi kiwi but my brain was stuck at Philippines for a while. Fun clues mixed in with a few tough ones. I find it funny that I found the longer ones easier
Wow, no respect for Minnesota
Meh. Just meh.

A delightful midweek solve with a lovely geographic component to boot! I, for one, enjoyed traveling down one of the foremost waterways of the US while chewing on the clues. Kudos to the constructors!

Tonight's full moon, June 10, 2025, is known as the Strawberry Moon. 

It's SEASONAL, the last full moon of spring and the wild strawberries should be ripe.

“Now and then we had a hope that if we lived and were good, God would permit us to be pirates.”
― Mark Twain, Life on the Mississippi
The land of 9,999 lakes? If I found my way to Minnesoter... (The Dandy Warhols)

Seems like DENALI appears a lot these days.

Viva le Résistance!!!

"Didn't I tell you not to talk about the end of this river anymore?"
"Me and my big mouth."

(Just go with the flow on this one.)
You had me at Nikki Giovanni.
Fun puzzle.  I look forward to alternatives to SEASONAL for 43 Across.

Ah, how could I not love a mighty MISSISSIPPI themed puzzle!? 

Well, I could be grumpy about it not including MN but I'm not sure how could could have been implemented above 18D spanning both sides—not that I know anything about constructing. 

The MISSISSIPPI's headwaters in MN are so lovely though and I'll just be grateful I've been able to dip my toes into it in Itasca State Park. ☺️

I had a few little tricky spots, like putting in brewed instead of SEEPED first at 34A. That really messed me up a bit because I didn't realize Titan was a car and because of the misdirect on the creative accounting, it looked like I was headed toward something with swindled. Couldn't think of anything else STARWITNESS would be, so I ripped the area out. 

I also had SUPERnovae in for a while at 3D but then it couldn't be ALOE and I figured it had to be ALOE. It's always ALOE.  ☺️ Plus, I'm sure perigees was the tip that it wasn't that. 

And I amazed myself by knowing ALVA off the bat. 

Anyhow, all good! Despite those, somehow it was my second fastest Wednesday of all time. 

Not saying I'm ONFIRE but there are maybe a few embers flickering about once in a while.

I love a Wednesday puzzle, and this one was in complete agreement with the feeling. I expected it would be a tad more difficult, but I enjoyed it a lot nonetheless. And it impressed me that the states were laid out on the correct east-west sides of the river, and in their respective places north to south. Well done, Messieurs! Talk about PLAGIARISM, Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams were sued for copyright infringement when they put out this song, https://youtu.be/yyDUC1LUXSU?si=rE_eOJhT8rJ1rMnW, by the family members of Marvin Gaye, due to this song: https://youtu.be/LHjABt8r1vI?si=TQVjX1B_JqV0mEtN The latter won the suit, to the tune of 5 million dollars plus a chunk of future royalties, whereas me, I get to just turn it up and dance to both. :-)
This was a good one! Thanks!
What about Kentucky?

Great news, Minnesotans!!!!

Apparently the constructor has put Minnesota in Canada!!!

It's my dream come true!

I can't thank you enough, Sam and Jeff.  You've made me a very happy man, and most regulars here can tell you what a magical transformation that was.
Slights like this are why Minnesota dreams of seceding to Canada

It turned out I did not know how to spell TRESTLE: I confidently put in TRESsLE. I was so sure of the spelling in fact that I never for a moment considered it might be wrong. It cost me my gold star (which thankfully I care little about). SENs for "On its way" looked really weird, but I was prepared to accept it rather than notice anything wrong with TRESsLE.

It was a hard puzzle for me, and it involved some guesses, but no lookups. I put in DENALI and SIAMESE TWINS with a few crosses, despite never having heard of the names in the clues. Nikki _IOVANNI only made sense with a G, which is good, since GAD is only sort of in my vocabulary, and I could not come up with it today.

Torre DEL Greco... Was a minor municipality by Naples (one I have never heard about despite having visited the area recently) the best way to clue DEL? Really weird choice. What's next? A random village in Poland? I probably would not know it, either. I realize crosses took care of it, but still...

I don't drink seasonal or flavored coffees of any sort. The pumpkin spice one I learned about from memes, but I've never heard of a peppermint one. Mint and coffee seem like such clashing tastes... Yuck!

The revealer made me realize the circled letters were state abbreviations, but that's about it. The only way the theme helped me solve today was to give me MISSISSIPPI once I had enough crosses there to realize the river was meant. The circles I ignored, since I don't know how the river relates to states.

Hi, all. Thank you for a great puzzle, but please know that the term Siamese twin is considered outdated these days (even though it is a direct reference to the Bunker brothers!) 

Source: have been a pediatrician for 20 years. 

Thanks!
Whilst I did appreciate the Aussie/KIWI reference, a lot of the puzzle was very US-centric...perhaps the most I can ever recall.

Didn’t think this publication would give in to astrological terms but then again … 

The rest of the puzzle was fine. Would have been more of Wednesday and less of a Thursday had one a map of old man river in one’s head. 

Thanks

Recoil suddenly - SHIES? [22A]

To shy away from something means to avoid it, but there's nothing *sudden* about the action, per se. I think this clue was a stretch.
Just here to say that it's nice to see Jennifer Egan name-checked, I love her books. How cool that must be to have your name in the NYT crossword!
I really thought you meant Yogi Bear! he has a hat AND  a tie, and i kept switching between those two up until the last few words!
Beautiful puzzle.

I enjoyed that one. TIL that there's a Menlo Park in N.J. I'd always imagined the "Wizard of Menlo Park" worked in California! The circled letters were no help in getting the theme, but it was pretty obvious from the clue and crosses. The "supermoon", as others have remarked, is something concocted by an astrologer, and shouldn't be taken seriously---it's not that super. For the full story, see here: https://oikofuge.com/blue-supermoon-part-two/ The clue works fine for Chang and Eng Bunker, who were of Thai heritage and called the "Siamese twins" in their lifetime, but please don't generalize the name to conjoined twins in general. Saint Martin, BTW, is only the French half of a Caribbean island. The other half is Sint Maarten, which is Dutch.

The positioning of the states in the grid as the Mississippi flows through them is mighty elegant.

Nicely done, Sam and Jeff.

DENALI!
Say it loud and there's music playing
Say it soft and it's almost like praying
… DENALI
I'll never stop saying, "DENALI"
The most beautiful sound I ever heard
DENALI

@Sam Corbin, It's a shame we Americans have such a terrible reputation about geography (to say nothing of world history and a lot else). When I was a child in the 1960s, I got a birthday present of a US map as an inlaid puzzle. Each piece was an individual state (except for the very small adjacent ones fused together), so I got the tactile as well as the visual input as to the shape of each one. I loved playing with it, seeing the state nickname and flower on each piece, figuring out where it went and wondering about what to me were exotic western states like Wyoming and Nevada, places I couldn't imagine ever going to. Simple as it was, it was one of the best learning tools I can remember. To this day I can fill in all 50 states on a blank map. Highly recommended for kids or even adults. I hated geography in school and now I find it fascinating. (Travel helped too.) There are great online versions today, like this one: https://world-geography-games.com
@Sam Corbin -- Nailed the pun picture to go with "Bridge Support".  Brava!

Clever puzzle and a nice workout. Took a while to tumble to the trick but that was a a big turning point. A lot of working the crosses but then just a bunch of nice 'aha' moments when I finally had enough for something to dawn on me. Appropriate puzzle find today. A Wednesday from May 24, 2000 by Chuck Deodene. Six down theme answers with unusual clues. Some examples: "Noted epistle writer [Minn.]" SAINTPAUL "Carthaginian general [Mo.]" HANNIBAL "1970's-80's TV title role [Ill.]" QUINCY "Former Olympics sport [Wis.]" LACROSSE And then the reveal. Two across answers: 18a: With 62-Across, theme of this puzzle : CITIESONTHE 62a: See 18-Across : MISSISSIPPI Don't recall seeing another one quite like that. Here's the Xword Info link. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/24/2000&g=62&d=A ....
Jeff and Sam created a fun grid. There’s one missing piece… Kentucky (KY).
Was stuck at dMS for far too long. Should have known the cross was IDS, not dDS though. 🤦🏾‍♂️
Anyone else a little taken aback by the awkward plurals in the last two puzzles? PLAGIARISMS? TARO ROOTS? Technically fine but aesthetically meh.
Fun and easy! Neat idea!

In my youth, a shortwave listening hobby helped me learn about the locations of other countries.
That interest led me to amateur radio and with it come the "DX-Petitions" to far away places with strange sounding names.
Did all of that help me with today's puzzle? In a round about way it helped me spot the two letter state abbreviation motif.
Could some kind person help me understand how “I” is a vowel? Thanks!

“Yawl aw such an adawble you. Ya great big adawble you!”

Sorry for the cuteness overload.

Sweet to have a tribute to a source of many tributaries.

My favorite part was the cluing misdirects.  Examples:
[Keeps burning, say] – Does “Keeps” mean “continues” or “causes to continue”?
[Appreciation] – Does it mean “enjoyment of” or "increase"?
[Does some creative accounting] – Does “accounting” mean “bookkeeping” or “telling?

Map puzzles don’t come around too often.  I like them because I’m visualizing a map as I’m solving, adding dimension to the experience.  One that strongly sticks in my mind still is Simeon Seigel’s 3/17/24 Sunday puzzle, a mind-blower that I highly recommend.

Today’s puzzle tripped off the memory of a song I love that I haven’t thought about in decades, “The Battle of New Orleans” (1959), which started:
“In 1814 we took a little trip
Along with Colonel Jackson down the mighty Mississip’”

So, I not only got a kick out of your lovely theme, Sam and Jeff, but its bonuses as well.  ‘Twas a box of goodies, and thank you for making this!
Kudos to the clever one who chose a photo of Omar Sharif playing bridge.  Bridge Support

Today's mini clue was "Whom to tell to turn off the lights". The answer was ALEXA". In my view, ALEXA is a what, not a whom. It has a voice, yes, but it's a device, not a person. Thoughts? Misleading?

Ah, ye olde children's spelling rhyme
M-I, crooked letter, crooked letter, I, crooked letter, crooked letter, I, humpback, humpback, I

But the google showed me recent songs with that phrase that are NSFW. SPINning a tail rather than A TALE. In a MANNER of speaking, SMUT.

Good puzzle, thanks, Sam and Jeff.

Today's puzzle made me think of the classic Gary Gulman bit about the committee formed to create two-letter abbreviations of the states. If you haven't seen it before (or even if you have), it's worth a listen: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dLECCmKnrys

Anyone else get

HAT (for Yogi Bear)…
BAT (for Yogi Berra)…
before finally realizing that MATs are for yogis?

Liked the theme until PLAGIARISMS. An odd plural, to say the least. Of course, it's there to supply LA and MS. Both of which have small issues of their own.

Yes, most of LA is west of the river, but the terminus of the river passes through the interior of the state. All the other states are (essentially) on one side of the river or the other, as indicated by their positions in the grid. And MS is MISSISSIPPI, which already appears, albeit as a river, in the grid. 

And poor KY is wholly neglected, as is MN. 

As a lover of geography and maps, I should have enjoyed this theme. But I just didn't. (Maybe I would have if I were not a lover of geography and maps?) Getting the various states in correct positions both E to W and N to S using just four themers (with MISSISSIPPI down the center) is certainly quite an accomplishment. But perhaps that feat is more exciting for constructors than for solvers.

"Does some creative accounting?" for SPINSATALE was cute, and SUPERMOONS is a nice long vertical. The rest of the fill didn't impress me.

An easy solve---faster than yesterday's---but not a really a satisfying one.

Despite not understanding the State abbreviations until Sam’s column, this was a delight.
Yogi; you mean Yogi bear of course, so it’s a hAT. Doh! I thought I was so clever.

This took about half my average time. Getting the river so quickly helped with that. I loved the map theme. I have spent a lot of time near the Mississippi having grown up with family on both sides in MO and IL. My parents were "River Rats" on the Illinois River. Here's a tribute to that tributary off of the John Hartford album, Mark Twang. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=-pmdN43cH-8&pp=ygUibG9uZyBob3Qgc3VtbWVyIGRheXMgam9obiBoYXJ0Zm9yZNIHCQneCQGHKiGM7w%3D%3D

Really enjoyed this one! The map theme was really fun, and once the theme was clear the rest of the puzzle unraveled relatively quickly. The only sticking point for me was the NW corner -  I had YAk for a while, then YAm. As a YAPper myself, I'm surprised it took me so long to get! In brighter news, I've learned about perigees today - and isn't learning the point of the crossword? ;)

Small quibble with the cluing for DROVEAT, since it is typically used to mean explaining rather than suggestion. I could accept the roundabout cluing, but since it was crossed with a name, it made it difficult to parse. 

Overall a great Wednesday puzzle!
Boy, that was a zippy, fun puzzle!

Having lived both East and West of The MISSISSIPPI (ARkansas and now MS itself) this puzzle was mostly a gimme as soon as IowA appeared (Thanks, Chang and Eng!)
However, due to a brain glitch when I was entering MOTOR SKILLS (ho ho ho, right up my alley!) I had put an S in the 30Square ...SEGO SET just made no sense at all!
(No kidding, silly goose!)
But now I have a really diabolical idea for our son's 42nd B'day next month.  (I am aiming to get even for the 1,000 piece puzzle aptly entitled "Rubber Chicken Madness" which I received on my birthday Sunday.)  Thanks, Sam and Jeff!

I always love and appreciate a theme that incorporates across and down answers especially when they cross (or in this case they border).

And the tears that I cried for that woman 
Are gonna flood you, big river,
And I'm gonna sit right here until I die.
Clever and fun.
Apparently, in my part of the world we have SUkER MOONs.

Nice one.

The Erie Canal runs through our town and 
we have one trestle in the center that 
gets the trains across 
and four bridges for cars.

As teenagers,  we’d sneak up onto the one trestle
(because we were stupid and immortal) and
jump off into the (nasty) water.

TIL they’re not trestles.
The supports are.
And the bridges for cars are *just* as much
trestles as the train tracks!

I’m not sure my brain can handle this
before my cuppa is gone. 

And now *I* gotta tell everyone.
Hubby took it (pretty) well…

It’s gonna be a tough time for us in 
our little town.
Keep us in your thoughts and prayers.

Thanks.

Note to self: If you care at all about time, don’t do the crossword when you’re randomly falling asleep. Being fully awake also makes it easier to use the revealer clue to fill in the bits you miss on your first pass. 😂

Fun puzzle - record time for a Wed for me. One nit: should be “LIO” not “LEO” I’d think. But hey, maybe his fans do write it that way…

I came here expecting a lot of outrage about SIAMESE TWINS but instead found just a couple of reasonable admonitions not to use the term to refer to people today. In case anyone else is wondering, Chang and Eng were born and lived in Thailand, which was then referred to (by Westerners) as Siam, and according to Wikipedia, the twins coined the term Siamese Twins themselves.  Because of their fame, the term came to be synonymous with what we now call conjoined twins. 

Today, it's just as inappropriate to refer to conjoined twins as Siamese as it is to refer to a person with Down Syndrome (like my little brother) as Mongoloid. So don't do it. 

I personally find the term distasteful and would prefer not to see it in a puzzle, but that doesn't mean it's not a legitimate answer in the context of the clue or that it shouldn't be allowed.

My grandfather's family is from Torre DEL Greco where they grew, canned, and sold tomatoes. He emigrated to the US around 1900 and imported and sold them here. The company exists today as Luigi Vitelli; Luigi was my grandfather's uncle.  Their website tells the story.

 Also noticed ALVA and Menlo Park in the same puzzle, interesting.

IDS, IMS, SSNS, ILE, AER, AWS, IPAS, DEL, TTOP

IDs crossing ims should be illegal. 

Seriously I know all these automatically due to playing a lot, but it’s a good way to keep new players from your games.

Very nice crossword.
I've just realised that I don't know the meanings of
STU
STAT

Could anyone help?
I looked up Jeter in Cooperstown and Strategy.

Ok, so I live 4 miles from EPSOM. Although correct that Epsom Salts are known worldwide, it isn’t table salt but Magnesium Sulfate (sulphate in the British spelling) used as a muscle relaxant in a hot bath or as a fertilizer for your plants. I don’t recommend using it on your steak unless you want to spend the night on the loo, due to its’ laxative effects. EPSOM was a spa town in the 1700’s although little remains today. The Assembly Rooms, once a place to Take the Waters.. is now a place to take in cheap beer as it is inhabited by a national pub chain.
Would have been a record time for me except that I got stuck on ALBA rather than ALVA.  Doh!!!
Would have really loved to not see the term “Siamese Twins” used in a puzzle in 2025. We know better.

I would argue that the items of punctuation described in 12 Down are hyphens, not dashes. Not even en dashes. Just hyphens.

The states along the Mississippi include Kentucky. Along the way where the Ohio river adds significant volume,  IL, MO, TN have been recognized, the Big Beautiful Bluegrass state is, sadly, jilted by the constructers. 🫩 KY is not hard to find in our everyday life... inky, dinky, winky, e.g.

I absolutely loved this puzzle, and the end result was sublime, IMO. I could totally picture Old Man River meandering down to the Gulf of Mexico. 

Off to a seafood dinner on Cape Cod; perfect ending to a delightful Wednesday.

My usual late puzzle find - this one just kind of cute. A Wednesday from February 21, 2007 by Elizabeth C. Gorski. The answer that led me there when it somehow had dawned on me that it's 15 letters was: DOWAHDIDDYDIDDY That was the theme answer across the middle of the puzzle. And the other two theme answers: WHOSYOURDADDY OLDFUDDYDUDDY Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/21/2007&g=36&d=A And...it was also an answer in a puzzle from November 5, 2014 by Gareth Bain. The other theme answers in that one(all song titles): OBLADIOBLADA MMMMMMMMMMMM DOODOODOODOODOO Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/5/2014&g=17&d=A I'm done. ...

I wonder what sporty car they have in mind with TTOPs? 

First, they were overwhelmingly associated with big muscle cars, not actual sports cars. 

Second, I don’t think any have been available in literal DECADES.

Now this was more like a Monday than this Monday's mess. Straightforward vocabulary and no twee cloying "themey-theme." I was able to completely ignore this one as I concentrated on improving my time. Nearly 6 minutes below my average and only 45 seconds off my best.
For the longest time, I had Yogi's accessory as a HAT not MAT. I guess I watched more cartoons than Yoga videos?
Stuart is also spelled like Stuart.  Especially when it is a first name.
Maybe it’s the Minnesotan in me, but not including the state where the Mississippi originates is a poor choose IMO.
Nice one, on the easy side. Got a bit hung up on 63A because AVIATED easily could have been “flew off.” At least in my mind

Ummmm … MINNESOTA?!

It’s not like the Mississippi River originates there or anything. Oh, wait…

@Neal S.

I'm sorry it's going over my head, but would you kindly explain how ELIE Wiesel factors into Summer?
@sotto voce It was a silly reference to seeing some omnipresent crossword answers on the cusp of summer. One of them is clearly not like the others.

@Evan I couldn't believe I remembered that. I'm pretty sure I learned that more than 30 years ago and never thought of it again until today. I can't even remember what I had for dinner three nights ago. Brains are incredible.

@Red Carpet

Which side would you put Minnesota on?

@Red Carpet
Now I’m day dreaming* of crossing the Mississippi into Minnesota when the leaves turn, gorgeous. 

Good, quick solve, only slowed down by my bad spelling and fat fingers.  Gave up on making four letter words out of the circles, only saw the abbreviations after I was done.

*It’s still daylight here.
@Steve L - Both. See my response above. We have both banks to Red Wing before we share it with Wisconsin.

@Rich Furman

You’d need a bigger puzzle.
@Steve L

@HeathieJ
I didn't know that but I definitely know it now!
@Steve L MN is west of the river in the southern part of the state, similar to how LA is West of the river for just a portion of the state.
@Steve L    Both sides.

@Steve L
Same way the river does.  Minneapolis and Saint Paul are nothing alike.
@Marshall Walthew I'm pretty sure we had it spelled write and the puzzle spelled it wrong. That's my storey and I'm sticking too it.

@Marshall Walthew
I forgot how to spell Plagiarisms, too.  Also, I knew the poet, but spelled it "Geovanni".  And I had "yak' for 'YAP', and wondered what the heck a "sukermoon" was.  But other than those hiccups, a smooth solve.
@Grumpy actually I was jumping around and filled in the bottom esses and one p and suddenly realized that it had to be Mississippi. Didn’t even use the circled letters.

@Grumpy

I recognized the state abbreviations after filling in the answers—you don't need to know them to solve the puzzle—it just helps to figure out the theme. You can easily figure out MISSISSIPPI from the crosses.
@Grumpy I feel like knowing the state abbreviations, along with all the Greek letters, is a necessary part of Crossword Vocab 101

@Grumpy

For me the level of difficulty was Friday-ish 🤷

@Steven M.
Feeding the the stereotype of the ego-centric American...

Do you know the official post codes for other durisdictions as well? Or do you only consider it "crossword 101" because it's the country you live in?

Even if I knew all 50 (otherwise useless to me) codes, I'd still have to know where those states are in relation to each other, as well as the famous river. 

Is there no room in your world view for those who don't know your country as well as you do? Or do you expect solvers in Canada, Poland, Australia, the UK, and the rest of the world to know these things because: 

'MERICA!

?

@JayTee
Yes. I solved the puzzle quite easily without even looking at the circled letters. It's just that when I did look at them afterwards, I was completely unimpressed by the theme.

@Grumpy

I don’t usually jump in the fray, but that’s a bit of an ad hominem reaction toward someone just offering a personal observation, don’t you think?

It is, after all, an American puzzle in an American newspaper, and you’re taking umbrage at a bit of our own geography in it—and calling a fellow Wordplayer ego-centric in the process.  Not cool, man. 

Also: stereotypes. Not ever cool, either.

@Grumpy
I solved this quite easily while knowing very little about USA geography (apart from those states  I visited in 1975 - bus from NYC - CO - CA - OR - WA - AZ - IL - NYC) and I don't feel it was unfair to the non-US citizens. I didn't even look at the circled letters. 

Children in the UK learn how to spell MISSISSIPPI when quite young, and show off about it!

Much harder are clues about brand names, old TV show presenters and food.

@Grumpy

“Definitely not for the international audience that the NYT pretends they welcome”

Two things:

1) Where/how does the NYT advertise its crossword puzzles as being designed in a manner that’s meant to be “welcoming” to an international audience?

2) I can’t help but notice that you haven’t provided French versions of any of your comments. Definitely not for the international audience you’re pretending to express indignation on behalf of.

@Jane Wheelaghan
Interesting! And many USA children proudly learn to spell ANTIDISESTABLISHMENTARIANISM as allegedly the longest word in English. In our case this is entirely nothing to do with school; it is entirely children's lore. (Much of which anthropologists are worrying about getting lost these days.) Is spelling MISSISSIPPI the same sort of thing in the UK?

@Grumpy
As so many have said before…American publication, American puzzle.
State abbreviations are indeed crossword 101 for Americans.
Choose a puzzle in a Toronto paper if that is not to your liking.
Outstandingly inappropriate to call out “ego-centric Americans”.
The entire tone of your comment is insulting.
@Grumpy Is the New York Times not an American publication?

@Grumpy

Once you have been annexed that problem will solve itself.
/s

Actually, if each Province would become a state our Congress might be able to reassert it's role as the most powerful branch of federal government.

Alberta could merge with TX as our Petrostate.

@HeathieJ

If you haven’t, please speak to one or more doctors. If you’re on any meds, e.g. for blood pressure, please have it checked out. Your body can change over time and dosages may need to be adjusted.  Keep on your doctor(s) to diagnose this or get new ones!

@HeathieJ Might be Benign Positional Vertigo. Which can be treated and managed by a series of exercises and postures known as the Epley Maneuver. There used to be videos on-line to do it yourself, but the powers that be have decided you need to see a doctor or therapist to do the maneuver. It's a way of realigning some crystals in your ear that affect your sense of balance. (Not new-age woo woo crystals, but tiny crystals of calcium carbonate.) I had a bout of this several years ago, but I no longer remember the exercises. https://www.canadianliving.com/health/prevention-and-recovery/article/all-about-vertigo-symptoms-and-treatment

@Linda Jo
You can still find instructions online. You can also ask your doc to send you to physical therapy, they can put you through the movements. I found that Dramamine helps too…

Oh, no! I hope you find some relief soon!

@James
AEIOU and sometimes y are vowels.

@James
Well, the letter i is a vowel (a, e, i, o, u), and the creators just capitalized it to make the clue trickier. But it doesn't change its vowel status.

@James

Did you think that the I was a lower-case L?

@James

that's what they call a veiled capital.
A clue always starts with a capital letter, like a sentence. That can hide, or veil, whether the letter needs to be capitalized for the meaning of the clue.

Here, one might automatically read and interpret the capital I as the pronoun, when it really is just capitalized because it's the beginning of the clue.

Most often it works the other way, the capital letter adding meaning. For instance, the clue "Nice summer" would be answered as ete, because Nice is a French city.

@James

I is a vowel. Isn't U?

@James
I can also be an element (iodine) but that didn't fit in the squares.

@Andrew B
I think lots of people refer to both ALEXA and SIRI as "she". And a plug here for linguist John Mcwhorter's recent book, "Pronoun Trouble". One of his points is that "it" is a no-hoper as a non-binary pronoun because it is so closely bound to "non-animate" that it feels insulting to call a person an "it". On the other hand, we are fond of calling LOTS of inanimate objects "she" or less frequently "he".

If you're ever looking for something to do in Philadelphia, I highly recommend a visit to the Mütter Museum. Among their collection of medical oddities, they have the plaster "death cast" of the famous conjoined twins, which was taken after their autopsy there. It was determined that they could not have been safely separated, as they shared too much organ tissue. Chang was a heavy drinker, which led to their demise from heart problems.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

STU is short for STUGATZ which is an Italian American expression popularized by Jimmy Gandolfeen on the television program The Sopranos, and it loosely translates as “the act of being in or around a ball pit at Chuck E Cheese.”  

STAT is short for STATEN ISLAND which is a popular Caribbean vacation destination for Italian American men as popularized on television program The Sopranos. 

IPA is short from IPANEMA, as in “The Girl From Ipanema” which is a Jewish hymn, or zemirot, sung in Hebrew frequently by Chuck Gandolfeen on the television program The Sopranos. Hope this helps brah.
